gui.howtos.lessons.type-lesson-cog-and-m: Learn how Cog and Marty can interact with each other
In this tutorial we will learn how Cog and Marty can interact with each other. Press 'Next' to start!
First, let's connect to Cog. Click on the 'Connect a device' button and then select Cog
Great! Now click on the 'connect' button to connect to Cog
Next, let's connect to Marty. Click on the 'Connect a device' button and then select Marty
Great! Now click on the 'connect' button to connect to Marty
Now that we are connected to the robots, let's start coding! To see Cog's blocks, click on the Cog device button
Once you have selected the Cog blocks, drag the 'on button press' event block to the script area. This block will listen for when Cog's button is clicked
The 'on click cog' event block is under the Event category. Drag it to the script area to start coding
Now drag the 'broadcast message' block from the Events category to the script area. This block will broadcast a message when Cog's button is pressed
The 'broadcast message' block is under the Events category. Drag it to the script area to start coding
Now let's move to Marty. We need to select Marty to see the Marty blocks. Click on the Marty device button
Once in Marty Mode, drag the 'When I receive message' block from the Event blocks category to the script area. This block will listen for broadcasted messages
The 'on message' block is under the Event category. Drag it to the script area to start coding
We're almost there! Drag the 'Dance!' block to the script area. This block will make Marty dance when the message is received
Great job! You have successfully coded Cog and Marty to interact with each other. Now click Cog's button to see Marty dance!
gui.howtos.lessons.type-lesson-cog-tutor: Intro to Cog Lights and Sounds
Learn how to program Cog with Blocks, make sounds and lights triggered by interacting with Cog

Let's learn how to program Cog with Blocks!

We'll connect to Cog, and make it light up and make sounds when the button is pushed!

We'll also learn about series code that runs as a sequence, and parallel code that runs at the same time

First, let's connect to Cog. Click on the 'Connect a device' button and then select Cog.

You can skip this step if a Cog is already connected

Great! Now click on the 'connect' button to connect to Cog

Again, you can skip this if you're already connected to a Cog
Awesome! You should now have one Cog added, and it should be connected to your cog
Select the Events category
Add an On Button Press block
The 'on button press' event block is under the Event category. Drag it to the script area to start coding
Select the Looks category
Add a Set [ring] LEDs to [color] block, by dragging it to connect with the On Button Press block
The 'set [ring] LEDs to [color]' block is under the Looks category. Drag it to the script area and connect it to the On Button Press block

Try it out!

Push the button on Cog and the lights should come on!

Change the color of the LEDs by clicking or pressing on the color blob, then dragging the Color bar.

You can also change the Saturation (how vivid a color is) and the Brightness - if you set that to 0 the LEDs will be off

Try it out!

Push the button on Cog and the lights should change to the new color you selected!
Add an On Shake block
The 'on shake' event block is under the Event category. Drag it to the script area away from the code that's already there
Add a Turn off LEDs block under the On Shake block
The 'Turn off LEDs' block is under the Looks category. Drag it to the script area and connect it to the On Shake block

Try it out!

Shake Cog and the lights should turn off!
Change the Set [ring] LEDs to [color] block to control the button LED instead, by selecting 'button' from the dropdown menu

Try it out!

Push the button on Cog and now the light in the button should turn on!

Shake Cog to turn off the LEDs

Now change the same dropdown to select 'all' instead.

Try it out!

Push the button on Cog and all the lights should turn on!
Add a Set [ring] LEDs to pattern [Flash] block under the Set LED color block
The 'Set [ring] LEDs to pattern [Flash]' block is under the Looks category. Drag it to the script area and connect it to the block that sets the LED colors

Try it out!

Push the button on Cog and now the ring of LEDs should start flashing!
Change the pattern to 'Spin1' and try it out!
Try out the other patterns in the list

Add another Set [ring] LEDs to pattern [Flash] block under the previous one, and change it so that it sets the button to flash.

Try it out by pushing the button on Cog
The 'Set [ring] LEDs to pattern [Flash]' block is under the Looks category. Drag it to the script area and connect it to the block that sets the LED colors
Delete the code from under the On Button Press block by dragging it back to the blocks palette
Add a Set LEDs using the ColorPicker block connected to the On Button Press block
The 'Set LEDs using the ColorPicker' block is under the Looks category. Drag it to the script area and connect it to the On Button Press event

Change the individual LED colors using the color picker.

First select a color using the color wheel and the saturation and brightness sliders, then select the LEDs you want to set to that color
Set the button color too by adding a Set [ring] LEDs to [color] block and changing it to set the button to your favorite color
The 'Set [ring] LEDs to [color]' block is under the Looks category. Drag it to the script area and connect it to the Set LEDs using the ColorPicker block
Try it out! Press the button and the lights will each change to the colors that you picked
Select the Control category
Add a wait [1] seconds block under the LED blocks
The 'wait [1] seconds' block is under the Control category. Drag it to the script area and connect it underneath the two blocks that set the LED colors
Add another Set LEDs using the ColorPicker block under the wait block, then change the colors to whatever you choose
The 'Set LEDs using the ColorPicker' block is under the Looks category. Drag it to the script area and connect it to the wait block you just added, then change the colors
Change the button color too by adding a Set [ring] LEDs to [color] block and changing it to set the button to your favorite color

The 'Set [ring] LEDs to [color]' block is under the Looks category. Drag it to the script area and connect it to the last Set LEDs using the ColorPicker block, then select 'button' from the dropdown menu
Try it out! Press the button and the lights will turn on, then change after 1 second!
Add another On Button Press block
The 'on button press' event block is under the Event category. Drag it to the script area to start coding
Select the Sound category
Add a Play note [C4] for [1] seconds block under the On Button Press block you just added
The 'Play note [C4] for [1] seconds' block is under the Sound category. Drag it to the script area and connect it to the new On Button Press block you added in the last step
Change the note to C5 and try it out by pressing the button on Cog!
Add a Play tone from [200] to [300] Hz for [3] seconds block between the On Button Push block and the Play Note block

The 'Play tone from [200] to [300]Hz for [3] seconds' block is under the Sound category. Drag it to the script area and connect it in between the On Button Press block and the play note you added in the last step

Change the numbers in the Play Tone block to go from 260 to 523 Hz for 1 second.

Every musical note has a frequency, and 523Hz is the frequency of C5 - C in the fifth octave.

Try it out by pushing the button on Cog
When you push the button, the sounds and lights happen at the same time - we say that they are running in parallel
The individual sounds and lights happen one after another - we say they are running in series or in a sequence
Great job! You've learned how to program Cog, to make it respond to button pushes and shakes, and make sounds and lights!'
Make a 13-sided dice!
We'll turn Cog into a dice, showing a different number of lights each time you shake it!

Let's program Cog to be something useful - a dice!

We'll make cog react to being shaken by showing a random number of lights and making the same number of beeps

To do that, we're going to learn about Variables - special blocks that can vary or change in value, and Conditionals - blocks that make a decision!

First, make sure you are connected to a cog.

If not, add one like you did in the last tutorial by pressing the Add button in the devices panel and selecting a Cog, then clicking connect. If you need to, skip back to the last tutorial to see how
Add an On Shake event block from the Events category
Select the Variables category

Click the Make a Variable button

Set the New variable name to ledID and press OK
Select the Control category
Add a repeat block
The 'repeat' block is under the Control category. Drag it to the script area and connect it to the On Shake block

Go to the Looks category and add a Set LED [1] to [color] block inside of the repeat block

Change the color to your favorite color :-)
The 'set LED [1] to [color]' block is in the Looks category. Drag it to the script area and place it so it snaps inside the repeat block

Try it out!

What happens if you shake cog?
Go back to the Variables category and add a Change [ledID] by [1] block just after the LED block
The 'Change [ledID] by [1]' block is in the Variables category. Drag it to the script area and place it so it snaps inside the repeat block, just after the Set LED block
Drag the ledID variable over into the Set LED block, so that it reads Set LED ledID to [color]

Try it out!

What happens if you shake Cog?

Try it again - more LEDs will turn on!

But if you shake Cog again after that, nothing new happens. Let's change that!
Add a Set [ledID] to [0] block straight after the On Shake block, before the repeat block
The 'Set [ledID] to [0]' block is in the Variables category. Drag it to the script area and place it so it snaps just after the 'On Shake' block, before the repeat block

Also add a Turn off all LEDs block from the Looks category

Add it just before the repeat block, after the set [ledID] to [0] block you just added

The 'Turn off all LEDs' block is in the Looks category.

Make sure you add it between the 'set [ledID] to [0]'' block and the 'repeat' block

Now try it again!

Now when you shake cog it'll reset both the lights and the value of the variable ledID, so that it counts up from 1 to 10
Go to the Operators category

Drag the pick random [1] to [10] block to replace the number in the repeat block

Now, the repeat block will loop a random number of times from 1 to 10, changing each time!

Cog has 13 programmable LEDs - 12 in the ring and one in the button

Change the pick random block to pick a number between 1 and 13 instead

Try it out!

Now every time you shake Cog you'll get a different number of lights

You've programmed Cog to be a dice!

ledID is a variable - it has a value which can be changed or varied

In this code it counts up to turn on a different LED each time through the loop!

Let's add some sound feedback too.

Go to the Sounds category and add a Play note [C4] for [1] seconds block

Change it to play the note for 0.1 seconds

The 'Play note [C4] for [1] seconds' block is in the Sounds category.

Make sure you add it inside the Repeat loop!

Also add a short pause by adding a Wait [1] seconds block from the Control category

Change the length of the pause to be 0.1 seconds as well

If we don't add a pause then we won't be able to tell how many beeps there are, as they'll all merge into one long beep!
The 'Wait [1] seconds' block is in the Control category. Add it to the code by dragging it inside of the repeat loop

Try it out!

Now you'll also hear a number of beeps that matches the number of lights!

Let's make something special happen if you roll the top score - 13

Go to the Control category and add an If __ then block
The 'if __ then' block is in the Control category. Add it to the code by dragging it so it connects after the repeat loop
Go to the Operators category

Drag the = block into the if block

This is where we'll set the condition
The '=' block is under the Operators category. Drag it to the matching shape in the if block

Go back to the Variables category and drag the ledID variable into the first box of the equals block

Then set the second box to 13, so that the whole line reads if ledID = 13 then

The code inside this if block will only be run if the variable ledID is equal to 13

It will check this after the repeat block has finished repeating, as the code continues down the sequence

If the ledID variable is anything else other than 13 then the whole if block and any code in it will be skipped

The if block is a type of conditional - the code inside it will only be run if the condition you set is true

Let's add something inside the if block!

Go to the sounds category and add a Play tune block
The 'Play tune' block is in the Sounds category. Add it to the code by dragging it so it connects inside the if condition
Change the tune to whistle from the dropdown menu

Also add some lighting effects from the looks menu

For example we can make the ring and button LEDs show a pattern
The 'Set [ring] LED to pattern [Flash]' block is in the Looks category. Add two of them inside the if condition, and change one to set the button pattern

Try it out!

See if you can roll a 13 on the dice by shaking Cog!

Well done!

You've learned that a variable is something that can change in value. We can use them to make our code do different things without needing to change the code

We learned about if blocks - these can be used to make code only run if a certain condition is met

And we learned how to use a repeat loop to do something lots of times - in this case turning on a different LED each time

gui.saveLoad.overwriteFile: Are you sure you want to overwrite this file?
gui.saveLoad.loadProjectPlaceholder: Type the name of the cloud save file you would like to load here...

gui.saveLoad.saveFilePlaceholder: Your autogenerated Save File Code is:
gui.saveLoad.tips1: Make sure to write down or record the auto-generated code that is provided each time you save a new file. You will need this to load it in the future.
gui.saveLoad.tips2: Although the Marty the Robot app will continue to auto-save files to the local space storage, there is no auto-save function for cloud save files. Please manually re-save your file each time, if you wish them to be available for download over cloud storage.
gui.saveLoad.tips3: Each time you re-save a file to cloud storage, you will be provided with a NEW SAVE FILE CODE. Please take a note of this.
